page.title: 04Farming Around Himbleton (3)
page.content: The other forms of intensive enterprises are Dairying and Beef production. The Dairy herds consist mainly of Freision cows - these being used because of their ability to give greater yealds of milk. With the advent of better breeding schemes the quality of the milk in terms of butter fat content and solids not fat has risen , as also has the general conformation and standard of the cattle. Most of the intensive beef animals are a by-product of the dairy herd i.e. all the bull calves , whilst the heffers are generally used to replace their dames in the dairy herd. The beef units are generally producing an animal ready for slaughter at 11 months of age having been fed on barley and straw.
